payload.heading: Who is Allah? – Advanced Study for Islamic Learners

inlines.text: In Islam, understanding Who Allah is is foundational to faith (iman), worship (ibadah), and ethics (akhlaq). Allah is the ultimate reality, the source of all existence, and the possessor of absolute attributes. This inquiry goes beyond mere definitions—it involves theological reasoning, reflection on the Qur’an and Sunnah, and understanding the interplay of divine transcendence (tanzih) and immanence (tashbih).

payload.text: Allah! There is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence.

inlines.text: The word Allah is derived from the Arabic root ʾ-l-h (إ-ل-ه), meaning divine being or object of worship. Adding the definite article al- makes it the One God, denoting absolute uniqueness (tawḥīd). Unlike other words for god (ilah) in Semitic languages, “Allah” is intrinsically singular, indicating there is no partner, no plurality, and no comparison.

items: Linguistic uniqueness underlines the Qur’anic emphasis on tawḥīd al-rububiyyah (Lordship), tawḥīd al-asma wa al-sifat (Names and Attributes), and tawḥīd al-‘ibadah (worship).
Allah’s name appears over 2,500 times in the Qur’an, emphasizing His centrality.

payload.text: Say, 'He is Allah, [who is] One, Allah, the Eternal Refuge. He neither begets nor is born, nor is there to Him any equivalent.'

payload.heading: 2. Allah as the Necessary and Self-Subsistent Being

inlines.text: Advanced Islamic philosophy, particularly in the works of Al-Fārābī, Ibn Sīnā, and Al-Ghazālī, describes Allah as Wājib al-Wujūd (Necessary Existent). Everything else in the universe is contingent, dependent upon Allah for existence.

items: Allah’s essence is independent: He exists necessarily.
The universe is contingent: its existence is borrowed, dependent upon Allah’s will.
This reasoning forms the philosophical underpinning for tawḥīd al-rububiyyah.

payload.text: To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And sufficient is Allah as Disposer of affairs.
Allah has ninety-nine names, one hundred less one; whoever enumerates them will enter Paradise.

items: Existence (wujūd): Allah necessarily exists.
Life (ḥayāt): He is ever-living, unending in life.
Knowledge (‘ilm): Absolute knowledge encompassing all times and possibilities.
Will (irādah): Unrestricted and sovereign.
Power (qudrah): Unlimited authority over creation.
Speech (kalam): The Qur’an as an eternal attribute of Allah.

payload.text: Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth…

items: Creation (khalaq): Bringing existence from nonexistence.
Sustenance (rizq): Provision for all beings.
Guidance (hidayah): Directing hearts toward truth.
Judgment (ḥukm): Executing justice in the universe.

payload.text: Attributes do not imply composition or division in Allah; they are descriptions of perfection, not parts of Allah.

inlines.text: Islamic theology balances absolute transcendence with closeness to creation:

payload.text: There is nothing like unto Him.
And We have already created man and know what his soul whispers to him, and We are closer to him than [his] jugular vein.

inlines.text: Sufism emphasizes experiential knowledge of Allah, complementing intellectual understanding:

items: Tajallī (Divine Manifestation): Allah manifests His attributes in creation without compromising transcendence.
Tawḥīd al-Shuhūd (Unity of Witnessing): Seeing all events as reflections of Allah’s will.

inlines.text: Through dhikr, contemplation, and reflection on the Qur’an, students develop awareness of Allah’s presence in every moment.

payload.text: Remember Allah in times of ease, and He will remember you in times of difficulty.

payload.heading: 6. Allah in Relation to Human Understanding

inlines.text: Advanced learners should consider epistemology: how humans can know Allah:

items: Through revelation (waḥy): The Qur’an and Sunnah provide definitive knowledge.
Through reasoning (‘aql): Philosophical inquiry confirms His necessity, unity, and attributes.
Through reflection (tafakkur): Observing the universe inspires awe of His perfection.

payload.text: Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and day are signs for those of understanding.

inlines.text: Islam affirms Allah’s absolute oneness in contrast with polytheism. Comparisons with Judaism and Christianity highlight shared monotheistic roots while clarifying the Islamic stance against divine plurality or incarnation.
For advanced Islamic learners, knowing Allah is both intellectual and spiritual:

items: Intellectual: Understanding His essence, attributes, and unity.
Spiritual: Experiencing His presence, aligning life with His will, and internalizing tawḥīd in thought, action, and worship.

payload.text: And Allah invites to the Home of Peace and guides whom He wills to a straight path.

inlines.text: Reflect on these portions daily, link them to Qur’anic study and hadith memorization, and use them to deepen both understanding and devotion.
